channel.title: HTML Energy
channel.description: HTML energy is all around us and in every website. Building websites has become complex, but the energy of HTML persists. What makes HTML special is its simplicity. HTML isn’t a vast language, yet you can do a lot with it. Anyone who wants to publish on the web can write HTML. This accessibility and ease of use is where its energy resides. In this podcast, we talk to people about their relationship with HTML energy—how they first encountered it, how they harness it, and where it's going. Who's writing HTML today?
channel.itunes:summary: HTML energy is all around us and in every website. Building websites has become complex, but the energy of HTML persists. What makes HTML special is its simplicity. HTML isn’t a vast language, yet you can do a lot with it. Anyone who wants to publish on the web can write HTML. This accessibility and ease of use is where its energy resides. In this podcast, we talk to people about their relationship with HTML energy—how they first encountered it, how they harness it, and where it's going. Who's writing HTML today?

item.title: Neta Bomani & Ritu Ghiya
item.author: htmlenergy@gmail.com (HTML Energy)
item.description:
Neta Bomani (https://netabomani.com) is a worker who engages in social practices like oral history and direct action through organizing and making archives, writings, prints, zines, computational objects and workshops.

Ritu Ghiya (https://www.r-i-t-u.com) is an artist who works as a designer and web developer. Her digital works involve retrieving and archiving personal and collective ephemera – in an attempt to channel the serendipity of the offline world.
item.content:encoded:
Neta Bomani (https://netabomani.com) is a worker who engages in social practices like oral history and direct action through organizing and making archives, writings, prints, zines, computational objects and workshops.

Ritu Ghiya (https://www.r-i-t-u.com) is an artist who works as a designer and web developer. Her digital works involve retrieving and archiving personal and collective ephemera – in an attempt to channel the serendipity of the offline world.
item.itunes:author: Neta Bomani, Ritu Ghiya, & Laurel Schwulst
item.itunes:summary:
We interviewed Ritu and Neta together because they recently collaborated on the website https://maskon.zone, a mostly text-based protest guide focused around anti-surveillance.
This experimental epsidode was recorded asynchronously over the encrypted messaging app Telegram from July 17–24, 2020.
We also explore Ritu and Neta’s collaboration and friendship.
item.itunes:title: Neta Bomani & Ritu Ghiya

item.title: Marie Otsuka
item.author: htmlenergy@gmail.com (HTML Energy)
item.description: Marie Otsuka (http://motsuka.com) is a designer working around tools and methods for making. She designed and developed the solar powered version of the Low-Tech Magazine website (http://solar.lowtechmagazine.com). This episode was originally recorded in New York on December 30, 2019, not too long after Marie returned from Barcelona, where the solar-powered server of Low-Tech Magazine lives.
item.content:encoded: Marie Otsuka (http://motsuka.com) is a designer working around tools and methods for making. She designed and developed the solar powered version of the Low-Tech Magazine website (http://solar.lowtechmagazine.com). This episode was originally recorded in New York on December 30, 2019, not too long after Marie returned from Barcelona, where the solar-powered server of Low-Tech Magazine lives.
item.itunes:author: Marie Otsuka & Laurel Schwulst
item.itunes:summary: Marie Otsuka is a designer working around tools and methods for making. She designed and developed the solar powered version of the Low-Tech Magazine website.
item.itunes:title: Marie Otsuka

item.title: Becca Abbe
item.author: htmlenergy@gmail.com (HTML Energy)
item.description: Becca Abbe (http://cdxs.ist) is a designer based in New York whose practice Cdxs, LLC focuses on typesetting, branding, programming, print, and digital. This episode was originally recorded inside Becca, Laurel, and Amelia’s home on November 9, 2019.
